items.standfirst: Police are investigating the sudden deaths of a mother and daughter whose bodies were found at a property in Kenmore Hills in Brisbane.
items.content: Police are investigating the sudden deaths of a mother and daughter whose bodies were found at a property in Kenmore Hills in Brisbane.

items.title: Mother and child found dead inside luxury property in Brisbane's west
items.standfirst: Police are investigating after the bodies were found following a welfare check at a Kenmore Hills home about 12.45pm yesterday.
items.content: A mother and child have been found dead inside a property in Brisbane's west.Police are investigating after the bodies were discovered following a welfare check at a home on Tinarra Cresent in Kenmore Hills about 12.45pm yesterday.A 54-year-old woman from Norman Park and an eight-year-old girl were found at the scene. READ MORE: Aussie industry worth billions of dollars under threatREAD MORE: US, Israel announce Gaza peace deal - but will Hamas accept? A crime scene has been established, with police seen investigating the luxury property yesterday evening."Investigations are under way," a Queensland Police spokesperson said."Police believe there is no ongoing threat to the public."The sprawling property is believed to be a multimillion-dollar home which can be rented out on Airbnb. Vision of the home obtained by 9News shows the home is situated on a large estate with a pool at the back.Police have asked anyone with information or relevant footage to come forward.If you, or someone you know, needs support you can call Lifeline on 13 11 14 or Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The property is located in Kenmore Hills, Brisbane.

The property is listed as luxury accommodation.
A crime scene was declared at the property.

items.title: Clive Palmer’s multibillion dollar claims make a mockery of a tribunal that allows foreign investors to challenge court decisions | Patricia Ranald
items.standfirst: The billionaire’s last three cases are part of a growing global list from fossil fuel companies against government decisions to reduce carbon emissionsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastDespite the Australian billionaire Clive Palmer’s self-proclaimed patriotism through the Trumpet of Patriots party, he has registered his mining company, Zeph Investments, in Singapore and claimed to be a Singaporean investor. He then used foreign investor rights in two trade agreements with Singapore to sue the Australian government for a total of about $420bn in four separate cases before an international investment tribunal.Palmer’s first claim was for $300bn after he lost a high court appeal against a Western Australian government decision to refuse an iron ore mining licence. The last three claims for a total of $120bn are because a Queensland court refused his coal mining licence and a licence for a coal-fired power plant for environmental reasons, including increased carbon emissions. Continue reading...
items.content: The billionaire’s last three cases are part of a growing global list from fossil fuel companies against government decisions to reduce carbon emissionsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastDespite the Australian billionaire Clive Palmer’s self-proclaimed patriotism through the Trumpet of Patriots party, he has registered his mining company, Zeph Investments, in Singapore and claimed to be a Singaporean investor. He then used foreign investor rights in two trade agreements with Singapore to sue the Australian government for a total of about $420bn in four separate cases before an international investment tribunal.Palmer’s first claim was for $300bn after he lost a high court appeal against a Western Australian government decision to refuse an iron ore mining licence. The last three claims for a total of $120bn are because a Queensland court refused his coal mining licence and a licence for a coal-fired power plant for environmental reasons, including increased carbon emissions. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Shock as 'one of the biggest' black snakes slithers into children's playroom
clusters.neutral_headline: Large Snake Found in Children's Playroom

items.title: Shock as 'one of the biggest' black snakes slithers into children's playroom
items.standfirst: A family were left shocked after a 1.6-metre red-bellied black snake got cosy in their children's playroom in Sydney's south.
items.content: A family were left shocked after a 1.6-metre red-bellied black snake got cosy in their children's playroom in Sydney's south.The snake slithered in through the back door into the playroom at the Kurnell home yesterday afternoon. It nestled itself behind a dollhouse and several toys.READ MORE: PM invites global retail giant to Australia to challenge Coles and Woolies"I did not want that loose in the house," the homeowner said in a social media video. Tyler Gibbons of Shire Snake Wranglers was called in to remove the snake and was startled to see just how big it was."This was one of the biggest black snakes we've seen this season," he said."Well over 1.6 metres and weighing more than 1.25kg." The snake was safely relocated. READ MORE: The millions of Australians at risk of retiring into povertyThe red-bellied black snake is a venomous snake indigenous to Australia and is mostly found in eastern states.Australians are likely to be seeing more snakes around this time of year as the breeding season kicked off this month and will continue until April. "A good reminder to keep doors closed when possible, especially with the warmer weather bringing snakes out and about," Gibbons said. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Four teenagers charged over dramatic Bourke Street Mall police chase
clusters.neutral_headline: Teenagers Charged After Bourke Street Mall Incident

items.title: Four teenagers charged over dramatic Bourke Street Mall police chase
items.standfirst: O ne woman was injured after being hit by the allegedly stolen BMW in Melbourne's CBD yesterday.
items.content: F our teenagers have been charged over a dramatic police chase through Melbourne's CBD, which left a woman seriously injured after she was struck by an allegedly stolen car.The pursuit began when police spotted a car being driven "erratically" on the Eastern Freeway in Doncaster in the city's east about 12.30pm yesterday.Officers then followed the white BMW into the CBD, where a woman in her 40s was hit on Exhibition Street, police said.READ MORE: Nicole Kidman and Keith Urban split after 19 years of marriageFour occupants of the car then left the scene on foot. They were arrested a short time later outside Emporium Melbourne shopping centre on Lonsdale Street.All four were charged overnight.A 17-year-old boy was charged with two counts of theft of a motor vehicle and theft.He was bailed to appear at a children's court at a later date.Another 17-year-old boy was charged wit h theft of a motor vehicle, conduct endangering life, drive in manner dangerous, drive speed dangerous, drive speed dangerous, unlicensed driving and failing to stop at accident.He was remanded to appear a children's court today.A 16-year-old was charged with aggravated home invasion, aggravated burglary, four counts of motor vehicle theft, attempted aggravated burglary and two counts of theft. He was also remanded to appear a children's court today.READ MORE: Aussie industry worth billions of dollars under threatA fourth teenager, a 16-year-old, was charged with aggravated home invasion, theft and two counts of motor vheicle theft.He was remanded to appear a children's court today.Shoppers were forced to run for their lives yesterday after the allegedly stolen BMW was driven through a pedestrian and tram-only area in the Bourke Street Mall. "I t was just mayhem... people coming around from everywhere," a witness told 9News. A fellow pedestrian told 9News it was lucky nobody died as people were forced to jump out of the way of the moving car."Next minute this car has come straight down and I thought, thank God we weren't walking in the middle of Bourke Street Mall." Another said the incident had haunting similarities to the deadly 2017 Bourke Street attack, which saw driver James Gargasoulas kill six and injure 27 after ploughing into pedestrians." Bourke Street all over again. Literally," he told 9News.The woman who was injured was treated at the scene and taken to hospital.She is now recovering with non-life threatening injuries at Royal Melbourne HospitaDOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
